Fields.DialogueText: *RADIO STATIC*
*STATIC* ... is how it... *STATIC*
This is how it ends.
*STATIC*
Somebody turn that thing off!
This is the acting captain! If you can stand, get to action stations! I repeat, report to action stations! This isn't over yet!
@BATTLE
The acting captain, I presume? I have to admit, I didn't see this coming when you came on board.
Yeah, I plan to spend a long time reflecting on the improbability once I'm safely in the brig.
I don't think that's going to happen. Give me your arm, by the way - I need to check your pulse.
Sure, but it's still going like a pneumatic drill.
And I'm "acting captain" because a strange woman in fancy dress told me I was. I think you'll find the folks in charge prefer to go about battlefield promotions differently.
You're acting captain because the bridge crew was poisoned by that damn fog and because you managed to get everyone else to listen to you. Your new friend's beside the point.

Fields.MenuText: She's not my friend.
Try telling her that.
I know it sounds crazy, but I don't think she's beside the point at all.

Fields.DialogueText: Just as long as she's not your enemy.
No, thank you. Since she's all that's holding that fog back, I think I'm going to aim to stay on her good side.
Yeah. Well, that's another reason you're in charge, then.
How are you feeling? Respiratory problems? Hallucinations?
I'm fine. My breathing's good. Hallucinations....
Ones the rest of us haven't shared.
Don't think so.
Then by the powers vested in me by this magnificent stethoscope, I hereby rule you as fit as anyone to command this tub until we get to port.
The real captain's not back on his feet yet?
I don't know what's in that mist, gas, whatever. It's not the same stuff they used in the trenches. But it's bad, and the gas masks look useless against it.
To answer your question: no.
The Captain's lungs sound terrible, his esophageal lining is scorched, and he's suffering from seizures that would put his health at risk all on their own under much better circumstances than these.
And he's an acute case, but he's not alone. I'd say twenty percent of this crew needs to be hospitalized immediately and another fifty should be on bed rest for at least a couple of days.
I'm afraid you and the lady of the ship are all we've got, Acting Captain. No pressure.
*RADIO STATIC*
This is- *STATIC*
I thought the radios were down.
They are. Except for her. Whoever she is.
This is how it ends.
... Right. I'll leave you to it, then. Good luck.
Hey. Is there anything I can do to help with the wounded?
I think you're already doing it. Captain.
Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Yes?
Doctor.
I'm acting captain on the ship. Standing on the dock, I'm just me.

Fields.DialogueText: Sorry. Not how it works.
I don't know who you had to shout at to get all those trucks down here, but you did a hell of a job. Our hospital cases have disembarked and the first of them are on their way.
How are they doing?
You already know the answer - you've been in to check on them often enough.
Yeah.
Speaking of heading home....
You're about to ask how we ended up way out here, and I don't know the answer.
Captain, this isn't just that we were drifting off-course for a couple of hours. We're hundreds of miles from....
Thousands.
Something happened in that mist. I don't know what to tell you. I'm trying to contact the powers that be back home, but-
*ALARM*
Oh, hell. Get back on board, Doctor!
I... does this city have any defenses?
Us.
@BATTLE
Maybe. But I need to hear it.
Mm. Well, if we assume the hospital has the resources to handle them all, and that it doesn't get gassed, I think most will pull through.
But they're probably all headed home, and most are just never going to be what they were before.
Good. Still responsive.
She didn't knock me silly. Whoever she was.
Brace yourselves, people. It's about to get bumpy.
@BATTLE
I never made this many house calls in private practice, you know.
The bridge has a better view than most houses.
Mm. If watching flaming wrecks sink into the sea is your kind of thing.

Fields.MenuText: It is.
I'm finding it's growing on me.
Point taken.

Fields.DialogueText: How are you doing? Breathing problems? Hallucinations?
No and no. Our new friend seems to be keeping the worst of the mist at bay. She's apparently helping with targeting, too. And engine performance.
Food's still terrible.
Well, there's working miracles and then there's... working miracles.
How's my crew?
Your crew, indeed. We'll make a proper captain out of you yet.
And they're exhausted. Casualties are lower than I'd've expected, but if I could give them all cocaine to keep them going-

Fields.MenuText: Sorry.
I don't know how we're going to keep you in bandages, let alone bonus pharmaceuticals.
I know some ships go for that stuff. I don't.

Fields.DialogueText: Honestly, I'd settle for a few thousand chocolate bars. But they'll get by.
I take it we haven't recovered any survivors from the enemy ships. I haven't had any hypothermia cases show up at my doorstep.
As far as I can tell, they don't have crews.
... Pardon me?
I've never seen anyone on deck on those things. The guns just seem to load and fire themselves.
Nice trick.
Under the circumstances, I'm not a big fan.
... Captain?
Yes?
What the hell is going on out there?
I'll let you know if I figure it out.
Then you're in the right line of work. Or exactly the wrong one.
Then again, sometimes I watch people die. What do I know?
Whatever gets one through the day.
It is what it is, Captain. It's not like you used it up.
Suit yourself. In a perfect world we wouldn't need it.
Hey! Hey, excuse me!
If you've got a delivery, your timing's perfect. We're just signing the last forms and saying our goodbyes.
I'm the delivery. I want to sign up.
That's great. We're not actually part of your navy. I'm sure you can find a recruiter who....
If you're fighting the things that've gassed this city half to death in the past three days, I don't care whose navy you are. I want to help.
Who do I talk to? How can I apply?

Fields.MenuText: Right. Have you ever served on a naval vessel before?
Talk to me. Make it fast.
... I'm not above taking bribes.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm joking.
No. But I'm a fast learner.
Okay. Right. I don't know what the proprieties are here, and I know for all you know I'm a spy.
I'm not. My name is August Cassel. I've been in the diamond trade. My family is in the diamond trade. You can ask around Antwerp or London, people will know me.
We haven't seen a lot of diamonds in the last few days, Mr. Cassel.
Good. Wunderbar. I hate diamonds. I hate the people who buy diamonds. We've built this whole ridiculous empire on vanity and insecurity and all around us the world is burning!

Fields.MenuText: Noted.
Too much sharing.
My point was that you'd be pushing a mop.

Fields.DialogueText: Right. That's probably not foremost in your mind.
Sorry.
That's fine!
Listen, I don't mind menial labor. I'm not afraid to work. And I'm good with electronics! God knows I'm used to squinting and-
How about radios?
Yes! I mean, I don't have a huge amount of direct experience, but I've read books!
*ALARM*
Is that... are those ships coming back?
Yes.
Please. Please, let me help.
I've had enough of just watching things get worse.
... When the shooting stops, report to the sick bay. The doctor's going to want to give you a lot of shots. Some will probably actually be necessary.
Thank you. I will. I... should I present myself to the captain, or...?
You already did, Mr. Cassel. Welcome aboard.
@BATTLE
Calamity. Corruption. Destruction. Disease. Fire.
The mystery woman. Not ours. She used to just say "This is how it ends."
You think this is one of them?
Sorry. Stupid question. It must be. It's the only signal cutting through this toxic soup.
Injustice. Murder. You would call them destroyers.
Charming.
Ssh!
Cowardice. Despair. Malice. Paranoia. Mischief. You would call them heavy cruisers.
Those are... kinds of ships?
Yes. I think she's telling us who we're fighting.
Avarice. Confu-
*STATIC*
Get her back!
I'll try. But I'm 90... well, 75% sure it's a matter of range. Wherever she is, I don't think she's close, and we may be moving away from her.
Our ship's... woman. Person. She said she was already working to help us receive the signal as well as we were.
You've talked to her?
Ja. She's terrifying, but extremely helpful. Or maybe the other way around.
Mm.
Captain?
If we do some scouting, do you think it would be possible to find the origin of that signal? Follow it?
Well... if she's staying still, we can probably at least figure out a general direction. If we have the fuel to do the looking.

Fields.MenuText: The fuel should hold out.
Of course, it's probably a trap.
Thank you, Mr. Cassel.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad to hear it.
Why would they trap us when they keep on attacking from every angle anyway?
... If it's not impertinent to ask.
You're very welcome.
It probably is. But you make a fair point.
Anyway. Good work with the radio. This has probably been going on for days and we just didn't know.
You didn't have anyone else who could work the equipment?
Believe it or not, this ship is ordinarily a lot more crowded. It's been a... challenging week.
It was like that in the city, too. I... my family's considerably smaller than it was a few days ago. The mist.

Fields.MenuText: Yeah. I'd guessed that.
I'm sorry.
We still have a chaplain, if it would help you to-

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. Of course.
I'm sorry, too.
No. Thank you. It helps to see these things sink, and that's all I need.
Right. Okay, I need you to keep-
*ALARM*
Mist!
Right! Keep listening as best you can! I want to find the source of that signal!
I'll do my best, but-
I know. It's about to get loud.
@BATTLE
I've tried signaling back, as ordered, but there's no response.
Captain. Mr. Cassel. I hear we're going off on a little adventure.
Hello, Doctor.
We're following a lead.
Aren't we understaffed for following leads?

Fields.MenuText: I think it's worth the risk.
Where's your sense of curiosity, Doctor?
Hey. It's not like Mr. Cassel here is our only new recruit.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, that's right. We have another engineer. I guess the war is won.

Fields.MenuText: Ignore him, Cassel. The good doctor is snippy before he gets his coffee.
That's my position until I'm proven wrong.
Have a little faith, Doctor.

Fields.DialogueText: Only because I'm being denied cocaine.
I know. Life is hard.
It's easy for you to be glib. You can fire enormous cannons when you need to stay awake.
Permission to chisel that on your tombstone?
Denied. Conflict of interests.
I have a medical degree. I don't need faith.
Um. Have you two known each other long?

Fields.MenuText: Oh, yes. It's been quite a while.
Too long!
Actually, we just met a few days before all this started. I'm new to the ship myself.

Fields.DialogueText: That's right. Insult the man whose job is keeping you alive.
But time flies when you're having fun.
But sometimes you meet someone and it's like you've known them all your mid-afternoon.
Heh.
My ex-wife got custody.
Noted.
So, what is going on? I hear we're chasing a ghost ship.
Remember that radio broadcast on invasion day? "This is the end?"
Sure.
It's a recording. I think. I mean, it never stops. I've heard it all hours of the day and night.
But it's also given us the names of at least some of the ships we've been fighting. And it seems to be leading us somewhere.
In a straight line?
More or less.
As though someone just left the engines running and let it go until it ran out of steam?
You think it's deserted?
I don't think anything. I'm just trying-
*ALARM*
Hold that not-thought, Doctor.
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
Somebody sound the damn klaxon! We let them sneak up on us!
Visibility's awful.

Fields.MenuText: At least the poison mist isn't back.
That's no excuse.
Get to your post, Cassel. Not the time for chit-chat.

Fields.DialogueText: @BATTLE
Good work, everyone. Now get me reports - and ideas for how we make sure this never happens again.
Captain?
Speak.
I think... ja, I'm pretty sure that one of the ships we just sank had something to do with the radio interference we've been having.
You're picking up our chatterbox?
... I'm picking up a distress signal.
No, but it is an explanation.
Right. At least I can hear better than I can see.
What a charmed life we lead.
I have the details, Captain. They can't be right, but I have them.
They identify themselves as MS Batory. Polish ocean liner. They were cruising off the Canadian coast early morning on the first of September - when the mist came in.
They lost sight of land, their navigational instruments went wild, and they've been... just out here ever since. They've heard gunfire, but haven't come under attack themselves yet.
Off the Canadian coast. Atlantic?
That's right.
That's still a long way away.
Right. They couldn't have sailed that far, could they?
I'm afraid that part's credible. We were... something similar happened to us before we picked you up.
Ah.
Captain, if you think this is real, then... what do we do?

Fields.MenuText: If they can proceed under their own power, we point them toward the nearest harbor and move on.
It depends on what they need from us.
Civilian rescue comes first. Always.

Fields.DialogueText: That's probably... what, northwest France? Brest or something like that?
I'm not sure they know. They hadn't heard about Poland - the German invasion. The captain was ready to go steaming back to Danzig to fight back with kitchen utensils.
I'm glad to hear it. But I... don't really know what rescue means in these circumstances.
*ALARM*
GAH!
You should probably start getting used to the sound, Mr. Cassel.
I'm trying!
@BATTLE
Or Ireland. It would be good if-
Still no further word?
From Batory? No. Nothing but static. Or, really, more like hissing. It's like when those ships were skulking around a few days ago.
But why are they bothering? There's nothing out here but water.
And us. We've been making radio contact with an unarmed vessel of fairly significant size.
Everything we've seen suggests these ships are primarily interested in salvage and scavenging. MS Batory and us - we're a buffet.
What about the chatterbox?
You mean, why aren't they targeting her if they're homing in instantly on us? That does make it seem like-
Actually, I just wanted to know if you've heard her.
Not since early morning on the seventh.
Well, that's-
*BOOM*
Action stations!
@BATTLE
And that's that. Mr. Cassel, see if you can raise Batory. I need to go down and check on those-
Hold on!
You heard something?
Hello? Hello? MS Batory, do you read me? Hello!
Through the static - somebody said they were hearing gunfire. If it was us they were hearing-

Fields.MenuText: They're gathering again.
Is there anything you can do to improve our reception?
Damn. Maybe we should start sending up flares.

Fields.DialogueText: Anything I know how to do I've already done. I'm sorry.
Would that help?
If I were sure it would I would've already done it.
Not your fault.
But the enemy's getting closer. I can feel their breath on the back of my neck.
We need more lookouts.
That's her out there? The Batory?
Yes.
Does she have one of these guardian spirit things too?
I wouldn't let our friend hear you call her a "guardian spirit thing."
I think she understands I'm much too afraid of her to speak with anything but the greatest respect.
Point.
And, no, as far as we can tell, Batory's female passengers are all the paying sort. And from all accounts a number of them are in need of medical attention.
The mist?
The mist.
They probably have better doctors over there than you have here, you know.
I appreciate the humility - but they were on a two-day pleasure cruise that's lasted a week and a half. Their resources are exhausted.
You're having a hell of a command experience, aren't you?

Fields.MenuText: Beats being bored.
At least I'm not in this alone.
I may already have blown it. If we've lost the chatterbox....

Fields.DialogueText: You really do worry me sometimes.
You're not about to hug me, are you?
You think she was going in a straight line, right? You'll catch up again.
I was talking about the lady of the ship.
You really do worry me sometimes.
Apparently there are VIPs on Batory who are very eager to come onboard over here. Did you hear?
Foreign potentates? Heads of state? Film stars? You'd tell me if it was Hedy Lamarr, wouldn't you?
The highlight is a retired Navy man, I hear. British.
Teach me to get my hopes up.

Fields.MenuText: Sorry.
In fairness, I wouldn't tell you if Hedy Lamarr were there - so maybe you're still in luck.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you. Thank you for that.
So what are we going to do?
Well, all they want us to do is look over their instruments, give them what supplies we can spare, and point them toward Cork.
And I'm certainly ready to get back on the hunt for the chatterbox. But-
*ALARM*
Oh, swell.
@BATTLE
Joking aside - how are they still alive? I don't even think we've gone twenty-four hours straight without getting battered senseless since this all started, and we have advantages they don't.
I know. I think they may just be the luckiest ship on the seven seas. Now we have to keep them that way somehow - ideally without letting the chatterbox get any further away.
See anything interesting, Mr. Cassel?
Not really, Captain. I was watching the Batory fade off into the distance... but I suppose that was a while back. I'm not late for my shift, am I?

Fields.MenuText: This conversation would be much less relaxed if you were.
No. But we'll need you at your post soon.
Incredibly late. I'm afraid you'll be walking the plank.

Fields.DialogueText: Right. Makes sense.
I'll be there.
We have a plank?
Planks can be improvised.
... So. Any regrets?
Strange question. No offense.

Fields.MenuText: Not that strange.
No offense taken.

Fields.DialogueText: It's just that you jumped onto the nearest warship and upended your life without a whole lot of preparation. Now that you've had a few days to think about it....
I've been too tired to think. It's been good for me.
And now I'm hob-nobbing with a famous actress. I'm actually moving up in the world!

Fields.MenuText: Message received. Changing the subject.
You're hob-nobbing with Fanny Verbiest?

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you.
Well, we're not exactly close, but she's been serving meals in the galley.

Fields.MenuText: "Hob-nobbing?" Really?

Fields.DialogueText: ... I hope it means what I think it means.
What do you say we continue this conversation on the way to the bridge? It's about time we get moving, and we should start broadcasting our messages within an hour or so after that.
Drawing attention away from our Ireland-bound friends?
And hopefully encouraging the chatterbox to keep talking so we can find her. Yeah.
I didn't say it was a great plan. But it's what we've got.
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
Enter!
Hello, Captain. Is this a good time to talk?

Fields.MenuText: Of course. I wouldn't have invited you otherwise.
As good as any.
I'm afraid that depends on forces beyond my control.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course.
I should begin by thanking you for having me aboard. I haven't been on a warship in combat conditions in more than thirty years, and I know you had no particular reason to believe I'd be of use.
More than thirty years? So, before the Great War?
Yes. I am indeed a fossil.
By the way, I come bearing brandy. Not the best, but what it lacks in pedigree it makes up for in availability. May I tempt you?

Fields.MenuText: Please.
No, thank you. I'll be on duty soon.
That's a bit too strong for my taste, I'm afraid.

Fields.DialogueText: Here you are. Cheers!
Of course. No sabotage intended.
Ah. I quite understand.
I have to confess, I'm not aware of many major British naval engagements at the turn of the century. Where did you serve?
Ah. Well, actually, most of the fighting I saw was on a Japanese battleship - Mikasa.
The boffins in London had an interest in seeing the Russians get a bit of a bloody nose in their Pacific adventures, and... well, I happened to be in the area, and had some friends in Tokyo.
I had a history with the old girl, as well. Mikasa, I mean. Family in Barrow-on-Furness and all that - I had a look around her as she was being built.
So, yes, I was there from... hm... September 1904 through the Battle of Tsushima in May of `05. Officially an observer, but in practice an acting boatswain - not so different from now, really.
Except for all the things that are different.
Indeed.
I take it you didn't see much of our new enemy on the Batory.
No. We heard the doom-sayer over the radio, of course, and there were times we saw... shadows. Out there in the dark.
August tells me they seem to have no crew.
You've met Mr. Cassel? Good. And, yes, he's right - apart from the strange women who periodically appear to taunt us.
Who are like the strange woman who periodically appears to help us. Just infinitely less charming.
Mr. Granville-
I was technically "Commander Granville" when I left the RN for more frivolous pursuits. But I propose you just call me Bertie.
Okay, Bertie. Would I be wrong to think you have a background in intelligence work?
Whatever gave you that idea?

Fields.MenuText: Call it intuition.
So, that's a yes.
We don't have a lot of time to dance around this, Bertie.

Fields.DialogueText: Mm. Well, I was never formally involved in much of anything, you understand. No titles, outside the Navy. Just service, when I could be of use.
So. Do you have any idea what the hell is going on out there?
No.
... Could you tell me if you did?
Captain, unfortunately, I'm out here with a woman I would rather like to marry. I promise you, I'm keeping no secrets that would help us stay alive.
You're pursuing exactly the same leads I would, and you know at least as much as I do. To be perfectly frank, that's part of why I wanted to sign on when you rescued Batory.
Well, that's-
*ALARM*
Hell.
If they're attacking us, then they're not attacking people who can't defend themselves, Captain. Chin up!
Huh. It feels strange not to be the one saying that.
@BATTLE
Well, this is an unexpected gathering. Mr. Cassel. Commander Granville. Ladies.
Hello, Captain. Just looking at the stars.
Actually, Mr. Cassel has been regaling us with horror stories from the diamond trade.
Not so much horrific as embarrassing. I'm afraid I've had a little too much brandy and a little too little food.
If I were a more petty woman, I might remind you that I've been trying to make you eat for days.
Darling, have you and the Captain been formally introduced?
We have not. Capitaine, Fanny Verbiest - at your service. Formerly of stage and screen, lately of a fine gas cooker near you.
See, Captain? Hob-nobbing.
My dear Mr. Cassel, delightful as you are, I'm afraid we don't know each other nearly well enough for you to nob my hob in public.
... Guh?
You mustn't look so scandalized, August. You'll only encourage her.
I am very easily encouraged.

Fields.MenuText: I saw you perform once, around 1928, at the Opéra-Comique. It was wonderful.
Well, I'm very encouraging. We should get along well.
Good to meet you.

Fields.DialogueText: You must have been very young. I know I was very young.
You hear that, Bertie? I'm now part of a matching set!
And you, Capitaine. Thank you so much for your hospitality.
She's about to announce that you should wear matching uniforms.
It's true, Capitaine. I have another dress just like this one, and you would look divine.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I'll have to raid your closet.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, thank *you* for doing so much for crew morale.
Anyway. I'm sorry to intrude, but I need to borrow Mr. Cassel here.
The chatterbox?
That's what I'm hoping to find out. We're hearing something in the static, but you're the best we've got at homing in on stray signals.
Right. I'm on my way.
He's a good kid.
I'd be shocked if he's even ten years younger than you.
Surely you could find a more flattering way to-
*ALARM*
Damn. Commander, get to your station! Ma'am, get to the galley and find something to hold on to!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Dress uniform is more my speed.

Fields.DialogueText: You wouldn't be caught dead in this, would you?
I'd prefer not to be caught dead at all.
Maybe I'll defend it to my last breath.
So you're telling me it'll have to be a stealth operation.
*KNOCK*
Enter.
You know, the last time we talked, you told me to go into the kitchen.

Fields.MenuText: Hello, Mrs. Verbiest.
That's your station.
I meant it in the most flattering way possible.

Fields.DialogueText: Hello to you, too.
Of course it is!
Oh, no worries, Capitaine. My ego is far too healthy to be shaken by words spoken just before explosions start.
Have you considered that the women you took on board from the Batory might be able to do more than just cooking and serving meals?

Fields.MenuText: Sure. But you've all been through a lot, and it didn't seem appropriate to ask.
Oh, believe me, I'm aware. But you're talking about untrained civilians and I don't have teachers handy.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain. Some of the best times of my life came from being asked inappropriate questions.

Fields.MenuText: Do you have a specific proposal?

Fields.DialogueText: Sailors have learned on the job for most of naval history, darling.
I'm afraid I'm at a loss. Traditionally, officers have proposed to me.
I just don't want to be in the way, Capitaine. None of us do. If you really think the most effective thing for us to do when the shooting starts is to hide below decks, we will...
... but if you're short on hands to get powder and shells from point A to point B, please remember you do have extra hands.
It's not as though being below the water line will help us much if the ship goes under.
... It's a fair point. We'll work something out for anyone who wants to do more.
Thank you. I'm thinking particularly of Sayako, of course. Have you met her yet?
No. I know who you're talking about - she spends a lot of time drawing and stalking the lady of the ship - but she has a way of vanishing when I'm about to introduce myself.
Or ask what she's doing.
Or ask what she's doing.
She's Bertie's ward, more or less. Her parents were friends of his, and though they really had no choice but to disown her-
Pardon?
Oh, it happens to all the interesting girls, Capitaine. Anyway, they wanted to make sure she was looked after, and Bertie's always had a weakness for clever strays.
And she went along with it because she's simply mad for ships. Always has been. Machines in a larger sense too, I suppose, but I think a well-armed monster like this ship is her idea of heaven.
It would do her a world of good if you could find something productive for her to do. It would probably keep her out of trouble in the long run, too.

Fields.MenuText: I'll meet with her, at least. If I can catch her.
We'll see.
Okay. Here's the plan - I'll press-gang some of the crew into launching a training program.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know exactly how it's going to work, but if Sayako - or whoever - wants to be useful, we'll make it happen.
And we'll make sure it's a program that we can expand, and that other ships can emulate. Because I don't think this is a war we're going to win without grabbing all the help we can get.
... Here.
A rosary?

Fields.MenuText: I don't understand.
I'm not Catholic.
So you're saying I should pray for help.

Fields.DialogueText: It's the most valuable thing I have on me. If you're serious about this and need supplies when we get back to land - or need to impress a priest, I suppose - it might be useful.
That's all I can ask. Thank you.
You won't regret it. Probably. Almost certainly!
So! I never heard if we started hearing that signal again. Did August's exceptional ears save the day?
Not so far. We may have heard something, but we can't confirm it - and it's getting harder and harder to justify the search.
If you think it's important, I wouldn't give up too soon. I mean, surely they've already sent their worst after us, right?
*ALARM*
Well, that's just embarrassing.
@BATTLE
Captain!
I'm here, Mr. Cassel. What's going on?
I sent out our message on the hour, as usual, and... hang on....
*STATIC*
Dammit.

Fields.MenuText: You got a response?
Relax. Take your time.
I assume it was another round of static that might or might not have had a recognizable word?

Fields.DialogueText: Dammit, dammit, dammit. It was the chatterbox, Captain. And it wasn't just the recording. I think she said her name was Hope.

Fields.MenuText: And she's got magic unicorns for us.
Wasn't that at the bottom of Pandora's box?
Interesting.

Fields.DialogueText: Let me just-
*ALARM*
Right. This is going to have to-
*RADIO STATIC* Hope. Fight free. Come to me. I don't have much *STATIC*
Okay, then.
@BATTLE
Heh. Why not?
*STATIC* will change local weather patterns. Not control them, not at first, but ch *STATIC*
Tell me you're getting all this.
I don't know what I make of it, but anything I can hear, I'm writing down.
*STATIC*
*STATIC* st they will take your weapons and use them. Ap *STATIC* ximate them. As they remember themselves *STATIC* will become worse. More pow *STATIC*

Fields.MenuText: It could be disinformation.
You can't clear up the reception?
"As they remember themselves?"

Fields.DialogueText: Seems like a very inefficient way to do it.
If they make us fight for every word they say, we're more likely to want to believe. It's human nature.
You think they even understand human nature?
I think it's best we assume they do.
I've been doing this professionally for less than two weeks, Captain. It's a miracle we're getting this much.
Don't sell yourself short, Mr. Cassel. You're a resourceful man.
That's an order to try harder disguised as a compliment, right?
See? You learn quickly.
In fairness, I'm not sure she's speaking in her native language. I can't place the accent.
She hasn't made many big mistakes in word choice before now, though.
As far as we know.
*STATIC* ways to influence you. Ways to control you. Your own *STATIC* n offer some protection, but they must be *STATIC*
*STATIC*
Damn. Let me just...
*WHACK*
-to set you against one another, sister against sister and nation against nation. *FADE* ause some fraction of your people always turns against the rest.
No matter how desperately you fear each other, you must *FADE* to fear us more, all of you. You must.
They remember me now. Finally. They will be coming. I have a *FADE* which you will understand in time. But you have to find me before it's too late.
*ALARM*
Hope is never false.
Great. I'm glad somebody's an optimist.
@BATTLE
Is that her, then? The chatterbox?
The lady of the house thinks so. And the fact that she's not firing at us is suggestive.
She's enormous.
Aircraft carrier. Got to be.
Oh, look. We have a visitor. How delightful.
Kanchou! Hajimemashite! My name is Kirishima Sayako. I'll do my best to help out, so please look after me.

Fields.MenuText: I had the impression you've been avoiding me.
You're safe here. We'll see to it.
Mrs. Verbiest has told me good things about you. Mostly.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes!
... Okay.
I was afraid you would order me to stay below decks where I couldn't see anything, and it would have been wrong to disobey that kind of order, so it seemed best not to give you the chance to give it.
Thank you so much.
Then she's mostly very kind and probably honest the rest of the time.
... Have I mentioned my misgivings about bringing civilians aboard, Captain?
Yes. Repeatedly.
I'll try not to be a bother, Doctor.
But, anyway, look at it. The deck's obviously meant for aircraft - but can you make out those blisters on the deck through the rain? I can't figure out what they'd be for.
I'd think maybe they might be damage - the whole ship has certainly been banged up - but they're so regular.

And look at the conning tower, if you can call it that. Is it broken, you think, or was it always a weird little nub? I mean, if it's true that she doesn't have a crew, maybe she doesn't need a tower.
Kanchou! May I join the boarding party?

Fields.MenuText: No.
Absolutely not.
I'm sorry. How old did you say you were?

Fields.DialogueText: Twenty-three. I just look young. Trust me, if you add up all the time I've spent at various universities I'm basically a college graduate.
You know I'm good at not being seen. And I'm fast, and I'm clever. Look - I took the doctor's watch while we've been talking!
What the f-
Gomen'nasai! I'm sorry! Think of it as a magic trick - I just needed to make the point!

Fields.MenuText: Heh.
You're not going to impress me by looting my crew. Don't do it again.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? That's your response?
Hai! I understand!
We'll talk about what role you might serve on this ship in due time-
And where you got that uniform.
But I'm not sending you over to-
Do you suppose that's her name?
Excuse me?
There's something painted on the hull of the carrier. See? I don't know the alphabet, but it looks like two words.
What?
"False Hope." That's the way their names work: Despair, Destruction, Calamity. False Hope. She even hinted at it the last time we heard her.
Doesn't mean she doesn't want to help.
Yeah. But it-
*ALARM*
Both of you get to where you need to be.
@BATTLE
I thought you might say that. Let me make my case.
This is a recording. I have to sleep. If I'm awake they can find me.
I can be awake in short spurts. I've prepared for you as best I can.
I don't remember enough. I can't give you as much help as you deserve.
Most of what I remember is killing. So much. So many wars. We don't die the way you do.
I have something you need to see. I don't know what's on it, exactly. I made it before, the time before now, and I preserved it. You don't know how hard that is.
A film. I don't remember what's on it, exactly, but I know it matters.
She doesn't sound well.
She sounds like she's on her third pint.
Under the circumstances, I think that's unlikely, my friend. Feverish, perhaps. Wounded. Or even under duress.
Her engines took a few hits in that last attack. And she didn't defend herself at all.
She didn't shoot us, either.
Be that as it may, she's dead in the water, and I have it on good authority that enemy ships are inbound in massive numbers.

Fields.MenuText: I can't tell if this is a trap or if our luck just ran out.
I'd say we caught up with her just in the nick of time if we're going to save anything.
Thoughts?

Fields.DialogueText: Either way, can we shoot our way out of it?
I agree. But we'll need to move quickly.
None you haven't already had, my friend. We need to move quickly.
That's certainly the plan.
... Hope seems to have gone quiet again.
So she has.
Commander, I'm going to need people to go over to that ship and search it as thoroughly as they can in a very limited time. I want volunteers - ideally without family obligations.
I'll go.
You're needed here, son. Captain, I'd be proud to lead the group.
Bertie, I'm not saying you're not fit, but you're not the fastest man on this ship.
And Fanny would murder the Captain if anything happened to you. But, listen, Captain, the demon girl knows her way around a radio just as well as I do.
"The demon girl?"
He means Sayako. In fairness, she's been called worse.
I was never essential, but you can't even really make the argument now. Plus, having a radio operator in the party might actually make some sense.
... Commander, he's available if you need him. Get your volunteers and get them moving - I want them on their way in two hours.
Aye aye, Captain.
Mr. Cassel, if you go, don't be stupid about it.
Thank you, Captain.
*ALARM*
Dammit. Commander!
We have visual contact with some of the sailors on False Hope's deck, Captain - nothing seems too out of sorts.
But nothing on the radio?
Not for hours. They haven't sent up their flares, though - best evidence is that nothing's gone too badly amiss.
Except they're perched on the back of a sitting duck - if you'll excuse the awkward metaphor.

Fields.MenuText: If they can see us, signal that it's time for them to pack up and leave.
If they can see us, signal that they should hunker down. There could be bombers incoming.

Fields.DialogueText: Very good, Captain.
Get yourself ready. We're not fifteen minutes away from a hard fight.
We won't let you down, Captain.
@BATTLE
What's a few more hits to our derelict friend?

Fields.MenuText: In a strange sort of way, they might be safer over there.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose it's a nice place to visit. Well, nice-esque.
We took as many photos as we could, Captain, and maybe the engineer's mate can tell you something about what's left of the engines - but I couldn't tell you what we were seeing over there.
There was stuff that felt like eggshell that we literally couldn't break with a hammer. Oxidized metal right and left. Basically no electrical wiring.
And there were these enormous tubes. Glass, or something like glass, and fluid inside, and floating in them were thousands of... I don't know. They looked like spiders, but some had wings.
The walls glowed for no reason - except for where they didn't. And the way voices echoed in there... my God.

Fields.MenuText: Take a breath.
Tell me things that aren't already in your report.
You did good work. I don't know what it all means, but somebody will.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll tell you one thing - I didn't see wood. I didn't see anything that looked like anything I'd recognize as tool work. I didn't see rivets, I didn't see joints, I didn't see soldering.
Was there any writing? Any documentation?
Apart from what was on the film canister?
"This is how it ends." I give her credit for consistency.
Apart from that, no. There were smudges on some of the walls where writing might once have been, but... no. But everything was black. Maybe it had all been scorched, I don't know.
And you never saw the woman herself.
No. We heard... we thought we heard whispering. In the dark places. But there was never anyone there.
I suppose it could have been the girl, too. The Japanese girl. I don't know how she swam over there, but....
Oh, she's writing a full account during her stay in the brig.
Has anyone watched the film yet?
No. It's not the right size for our projector. We're putting together a workaround.
Captain... what are we going to do about that ship? We can't tow it, can we? And we can't stay here defending it indefinitely.
You've answered your own question. We're going to have to scuttle her unless she finds a way to help us help her. Maybe divers will be able to find the spot later.
If she really was trying to help us, it's... it's unfortunate.
I know. But it-
*ALARM*
If she's real, I don't think she wants them to get at her either.
@BATTLE
I can only imagine what kind of madman might.
Don't mind if I do. I swear I was holding it for the whole expedition.
*BOOM*
Status report! Who's shooting at us?
And somebody sound the klaxon!
I don't think we're the ones under fire, Captain! The interference is bad, but I'm picking up a distress call.
The chatterbox?
No. Cargo ship. The man shouting into the radio sounds French....
Somebody figure out where they are and get us there!
@BATTLE
Well done, everyone. Now get the fires out and tell me how badly we're hurt.
And Mr. Cassel, see if you can get our new friends on the radio.

Fields.MenuText: Ask them if they need assistance.
Ask them what they're doing out here.
Ask them if they have a machinist they can spare. Offer bribes. This mess with the projector reminds me we're understaffed.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain, no disrespect intended, but how much assistance are we in a position to offer?
As much as we can. Ask the question, Mr. Cassel.
Right. Will do.
Bribes? What bribes?
I don't know - I'll put in a good word for them at the nearest port authority. Just see what you can do.
Aye, aye.
Commander! Is False Hope still out there?
Just visible in the rain, Captain. They certainly tried to shell her, but she hasn't sunk yet.
Right.
Commander, if that cargo ship can sail on her own steam I'm afraid we're going to have to see her to safety. If not, we'll be taking on more guests.
I should think we should be recruiting regardless, Captain. Our numbers are-
Agreed. But my point is that things will be getting more complicated. If we're going to sink False Hope, I need to find a way that uses the least possible ammunition.
And if anyone can think of an alternative to sinking her, I'm all ears.
Commander? A word before the movie starts.
Of course.
I'm inclined to let your ward out of the brig. Not because I'm convinced she's learned any lessons about disobeying orders and swimming to hazardous territory...

Fields.MenuText: ... but because she's more useful on duty.
... but because I'm sick of feeding someone who isn't working for it.
... but because there's a non-trivial chance she thought she was doing intelligence-gathering for you.

Fields.DialogueText: I understand. And I know I've said this before, but it bears repeating - I take full responsibility for her actions. I should have impressed on her more strongly that-
It doesn't bear repeating, Commander. She's a grown woman and she made her own choices.
True. Have you seen her maps?
No.
That's what she's been working on in her time in the brig. What she saw of False Hope's floor plans.
... She really needs to communicate better.
I agree.
Do they line up with Mr. Cassel's?
By and large, yes. And I believe she found places the boys didn't. She's somewhat notoriously good at getting into small spaces.
... Are you saying I should leave her in the brig until she's done?
I'm not sure I'd go-
*ALARM*
They really do have the worst timing.
Agreed. We'll just have to watch the film after the shooting stops.
@BATTLE
The film obtained from the entity known as "False Hope" appears to have been shot from an airplane.
Then the plane pivots and the orientation changes. The picture drops with dizzying speed down toward something unearthly.
It must surely be ocean, at least at first, but there's no water to be seen - just the increasingly familiar mist, roiling with strange lights, and the enemy ships themselves.
The plane turns, to audible gasps from those assembled for the viewing.
At first it seems there are hundreds of these ships, and it becomes clear that there are actually thousands. Most are pristine - not the damaged husks that have been seen so far.
And they are still. Strangely solemn. One of the audience is heard to whisper "It's like they're at church."
The plane continues to turn, and a different landscape comes into view - the edge of a bay, and the sight of land.
But the land is ruined. The bare ground is dead and gray, and everything else is gunmetal or black - strange geometries shaped like the enemy themselves, but not built to look like ships.
It's like a city made of nightmares. And there are towers.
Then, between the land and the sea, there's a flash - bright enough to swallow the whole projection for a moment.
The sea is blasted, momentarily, into a strangely white disc. A cloud rises up from it; some spills down around itself, while more - darker - stretches up from the center to claw at the sky.
It all spills up and over itself, for a few moments holding a shape like a mushroom - and below, under it, the land and the sea and the mist and the ships are all smashed down and consumed.
The picture - the plane - starts to shake. Three seconds later, it disappears.
The audience is left with the patient whirring of the projector and an empty screen.
Similar flashes are visible in the distance.
... What the hell are they?
Captain, I have several questions. Misgivings, if I may be candid.
You've proven your stenography chops. We both saw the film. Let's read over your transcript before we set it aside.
The proper authorities. Whoever they end up being. If there end up being any. We were unlucky enough to have to see it. Nobody else has to.
God willing. Ahem...
The camera is initially angled upward, and wheels across a vast field of bruised and black storm clouds.
"A city made of nightmares?"
It was the first thing that came to mind. It... still hasn't left.
Take the rest of the day off. I think the Commander still has some brandy.
Okay. I... thank you, Captain.
I can't argue with that.
Set it aside for... ?
Captain? It's good of you to make the time. I'm Enoch McPhee, and I guess I'm the commanding officer of the Lune d'Hécate.
I spoke with Capitaine Dortet the other day....
Mist relapse. Your doctor's doing what he can for him, but I guess it isn't looking too good.
I'm sorry.
I appreciate that.
From Harlem, originally. It's been a while.
Listen, I don't want to take up any more of your time than I have to. The fact of the matter is the Lune is done.
Da. Entirely.
Dammit. Captain, this is Lugin-
First officer on the cursed ship.
Who the hell said you're first officer?
If you want to pick someone unconscious, I suppose I can't stop you.
Whatever.
Captain, the ship's still seaworthy - somehow - but we don't have the men to sail her well and we don't have the means to defend her.
It's obvious you've got one of those Belles onboard, so we all reckon that-
"Belles?"
That's what they're calling the ship... ghosts.
The most polite thing, anyway.
Don't start, man.
The point is, you have a magic woman who's keeping you all from choking to death on the morning dew and we want to volunteer.
... Yeah. That is actually the point.
If you can use the boat and the fuel, she's yours. Same for the cargo, as far as I'm concerned - our employers sent us out knowing the best case scenario was an insurance payout.
If we leave her on her own, one of these Morgana things is just going to hit it with a bug swarm, dismantle it, and use it to build itself a nice new gun or-
Wait. Bug swarm?
You haven't seen these things hit the cities, have you? They send out these... things. Like locusts. Anything that can't defend itself gets taken apart and brought back to the ship to be re-used.
For repairs.
Or improvements, yeah. That's the rumor, anyway.
We usually just hear the screaming and see the fires.
Orest, man.
Captain? There's a certain look in your eye....
Do you suppose there might be a way to get the False Hope moving again?
Probably not a safe way.
Excuse me. People where I'm from usually don't smile when they say things like that. Are you English?
Yes.
This explains a great deal.
German on my mother's side.
Even worse.
Actually, Prussian aristocracy on my mother's side.
You see, Enoch? Cursed ship. We're all still doomed.
Please stop embarrassing us in front of the captain we're asking to take us in. We're not doomed.
*ALARM*
Ha! It's amazing how often I'm right!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You're American?
This your first command?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, yes. Two years ago I was in a cramped little flat in Paris studying history.

Fields.MenuText: How's your crew holding up?

Fields.DialogueText: Bravely. But it's tough. Some of the mist symptoms are obviously coming back.
Nyet! No! It is cursed, and I can tell you how I know it's cursed!
Oh, here it comes.
Because I found my way onboard! You see?
Ohayo, Kanchou! Comrade Lugin's just telling lies about his beautiful ship!
One. Is this the Soviet Union? Nyet! It's a lonely boat in the middle of nowhere and nobody has to call me "comrade!"
But we are comrades.
I'm afraid it's true, old chap. You've signed the papers.
I signed the papers "Lugin," so just call me Lugin! Easy, you see? Anyway, where was I?
Two?
I've forgotten which one that was! Doesn't matter! I was an innocent young carpenter's apprentice in Moscow, with a shining future ahead of me!
But fate... fate was always my enemy.
This is his way of saying he did something stupid.
I did everything stupid! Because of fate!
We've all been there, darling.
But, yes, there were disagreements, and perhaps I insulted the wrong small child - though, in my defense, he was extremely homely-
- and so the unkind stars and certain Party officials had me sent to Uzbekistan.
Have you ever heard of glorious Samarkand? The jewel of the Silk Road? The flower that blooms where the ancient East meets the surging West?
No!
Oui.
I've been there.
Well, that's not where I was! I was banished to the heart of the most forbidding desert in the whole of the world with no company but a camel named Mikhail! His only joy was spitting at me!
Actually, that brooding one over there reminds me of him.
I'm not brooding.
You kind of are.
... Just give me back my watch.
Enough! Eventually, alone with nothing but my thoughts and the accursed spitting camel, I decided to defy my hideous fate and make a new life for myself!
I would strike east - for China, and then Singapore. Fortunes could be made in Singapore, you know, and a man with a good head on his shoulders and a fire in his heart can have the world.
I would eat nothing but caviar! I would bathe in a tub of diamonds!
Don't get me started.
Shush!
So, finally, one cold winter dawn, Mikhail and I set out on a long and dangerous road. I was deserting my station, so the Army would kill me if I were caught!

And there were bandits! And treacherous passes! And a kind of cold none of you have ever known! A cold that slides along you like a snake as you sleep, ready to strike the moment you relax your guard!
And that damn camel. Worst of all, that damn camel.

But still, against it all, I followed my compass and my heart and I pushed my way east in defiance of the hateful fate laid out for me - until finally, finally, I saw the lights of a magnificent city!
It was Istanbul. I had been going west all along.
Well, naturally, I blamed the camel and chased him into a mosque, and there were... complications.
And finally the only way to escape a miserable end in a Turkish prison was to sign up to work on a ship due to leave the port immediately.
He swore he'd been a lieutenant in the Soviet Navy. Just for the record.
Isn't each of us a lieutenant in the Soviet Navy in his own way, my friend?
So. This is how I know the Lune is cursed. It took me in when no one else would.

Fields.MenuText: Well, now we're planning on feeding her to a mysterious ghost ship.
But now you have us.
Should we raise a toast?

Fields.DialogueText: Anyone could have seen it coming, Kapitan.
Also cursed. No offense.
I'm not drinking to that bucket of rust.
Well, I think she's cute. The Lune.
If you want to be her official captain for her last twenty-four hours, it can probably be arranged.
Hai!
No.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
*KNOCK*
Enter.
Do you have a moment, Captain?
We come bearing brandy.

Fields.MenuText: How have you not run out yet?
Thank you. Very kind.
Not for me. But, please, help yourselves if you're not expected to be sober in an hour.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, no one ever really expects me to be sober.
Excellent.
One can't be professionally decadent for as long as I have without learning a few tricks.
How are you, Captain? I rather think you're not asked that often enough.
... I've been thinking about the other day. Lugin's story hour.
And not the apocalyptic film?
Both, actually.
If we're going to have a future, I really think that's it.

Fields.MenuText: A lunatic Russian telling extravagant lies to an international audience.
A multinational crew. No stupid defensiveness, no paranoia, nothing but us and a common enemy.
Laughing in the face of absolute madness.

Fields.DialogueText: It's a fine crew. I don't know if this is your first command - but you assumed it under extraordinary circumstances and you've done a hell of a job.

Fields.MenuText: We're out in the middle of the Atlantic preparing to revive a potential enemy we don't understand without sanction from on high.
Thank you.
Same to the two of you, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. And it's the right thing to do.
You're very welcome.
Tell us more.
Heh.
You know... it may be presumptuous, but Fanny and I have been talking about it, and we really feel we're out here for a reason.

Fields.MenuText: Lugin's curse?
I'm not really one for divine plans, if that's what you're getting at.
Go on.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly.
Neither am I, usually.
It's just that... I have friends, Captain. I have contacts. Six months ago, I would have said that I was retired and that all that was good for was interesting dinner parties.
But now... you know, I think I can see how this all can come together. If we bring back the Hope, and the film, I know exactly the people who can wake the League of Nations up.
If we can bring all this to London - better, if I can get to Zurich - I think I can see how we can find a way to fight these things together. Or at least a start. A conference, I think.
And anyone you can't inspire I can probably blackmail.
We travel in similar circles, Capitaine, but we tend to have different kinds of conversations.
Ah.
Captain, assuming the Hope will go along with this - assuming we can even wake her up - you're going to need someone there on her bridge. I'd like to volunteer.
Can we even find the bridge?
Sayako did.
Maybe she should be capitaine.
You're as qualified as anyone, Bertie. I-
*ALARM*
We'll talk later.
@BATTLE
Better than screaming.
Such stuff as nations and religions are made of.
Doctor?
Commander Granville's fit for the mission, Captain.  Lungs are clear, eyes are good, and he's got the blood pressure of a thirty-year-old.
Whether the mission is fit for him, on the other hand....
The mission is limited, Doctor. Bertie, you get onto the False Hope, make contact with her Belle if you can, and see if she can repair herself and be brought back to the League.
The ship's been scouted, and there's no sign of any hostile agents. The main risk seems to be incoming Morganas-
That name really is a shame. I know a Morgana - lovely woman. She'll probably never have a granddaughter named after her now.
Perhaps not the most important topic of the moment, darling.
-and we'll do our best to keep them at bay. That said, False Hope seemed to suggest earlier that her being awake would bring more of these things, so be on your guard.
I understand, Captain.
You know, Fanny, the Captain here could probably marry us before I went over. If you'd like to have a go.
Don't be ridiculous, love.
Ah, well. Just thought I'd ask.
... Would the two of you like a minute alone?
No, no. Old conversation. Terribly sorry to have gotten you caught up in it.
Bertie has money, Capitaine. I don't. If I marry him, people will assume the worst.
They won't, of course, and I don't care about that anyway.
He's also trying to make a grand gesture so that I'll know he loved me if he dies over on that horrible ship. And that's preposterous, and I'm not going to encourage it.
Well, I do. I know people think of me as an immoral reprobate now, but at least I've properly earned that. I'm not a gold-digger.
Ah. Well, guilty as charged there.
Your confession has been recorded. Don't die.
Well, Captain. It seems I have my orders.
May an interested party ask an obvious question?

Fields.MenuText: Sure.
If you must - but make it fast.
If it's about their love lives, I wouldn't advise it.

Fields.DialogueText: Words of wisdom - but, no.
I'm just wondering what makes you so confident that the Hope will "wake up" for the Commander here when it wouldn't for August.
It's an educated guess - but one the lady of the ship supports. If False Hope really is on our side, then she's been waiting for us to make a plan. She should be ready to hear it.
And, of course, the alternative is being blown to pieces so the enemy can't get her. I would hope that would be some motivation.
Here we go again, people. Fire on my mark!
@BATTLE
You'd think.
Captain... look after Fanny and Sayako while I'm gone, won't you?

Fields.MenuText: I will.
In the sense that I'm keeping Sayako locked up so she doesn't swim after you, sure.
I don't think they're the ones who usually need looking after, Commander.

Fields.DialogueText: Right, then. I'll make contact as soon as I've settled in.
Good luck, Commander.
Meteoric.
I almost fancy my chances better.
Neither are you, and yet you've got that Belle of yours. Doesn't hurt.
Is everything on track, Captain?
Seems to be.  According to the Commander, False Hope is trying to stay quiet, but she's responsive.
I have my camera, Kanchou! Should I start filming?
Wait for the flare.
Hai!
You're going to record Lune d'Hécate getting devoured?

Fields.MenuText: It's an opportunity. I can't imagine it's ordinarily a safe process to study.
I thought giving Sayako something to do might keep her out of trouble.
Sorry. I know it won't be easy for her crew.

Fields.DialogueText: Do you mind?
No. No, I kind of like the idea of the old girl being immortalized. Even for this.
I know you've heard this already, but don't get distracted while it's going on. The consensus is that once False Hope starts this up, every enemy ship in the Atlantic is going to know where she is.
Assuming she gets her engines working, it's going to be a mad dash for Brest.
The goal is to get her there safely - or at least to sink her as close as possible so we have relatively easy access to the wreck.
So grim!
I wasn't gonna say.
I- Wait. Captain, what am I seeing off to starboard?
... You're seeing what you think you're seeing.
Can I film the battle?
If you can find a safe place to do it!
@BATTLE
It's not my crew I'm worried about. It's you.
Captain! There you are. Take the radio. The Captain's here, Commander.
Commander Granville?
Good to hear your voice, Captain.
Same to you. You're making good speed - but I'd be happier if you could wring a little more out of those engines.
No can do, I'm afraid. I wish you could see the state of them. The lady of this old ship is doing all she can to hold together.
Listen, Captain - most of what she broadcast over the radio these last few weeks was pre-recorded.
There's a collection of... some kind of magnetic tapes. The recordings. Might be a good idea to get those to the League.
Agreed. Does she have any equipment that would let us listen to them?
I'll ask the next time she appears. But, listen, she says the bad news is that we are being followed.
Some kind of battleship group. She says she thinks they're stronger than anything we've faced before.
We're just a couple of days out from Brest, Commander. Is there any way-
Not to hear her tell it, Captain.
Then we need to start preparing for what happens if False Hope goes down. You said she thought her "locust tanks" could be repurposed as external markers?
She did.
Good. And if there's any way to get one of those over here to bring back to a pack of hungry scientists, let's get it done.
Captain, amongst the debris over here is... well, it looks like a rangefinder, but it keeps screaming. It would take more hands than my team can provide to extract, but....

Fields.MenuText: Keep your distance, Commander. It's not a priority unless you think it's going to explode.
I'll set up some kind of special projects team to help you out. Work around it in the meantime.

Fields.DialogueText: I understand.
Very good.
Okay, I'll let you get back to work. We need you back aboard long before the super-battleships arrive.
Captain... one moment. Please.
Of course.
Captain, I've had the chance to speak with Hope several times now. She's not well. She's disoriented, and on occasion she's lapsed into outright delusion.
But she's unquestionably a real person, Captain. And a brave one, I think.
I'm... not terribly excited about sinking her to keep her out of enemy hands.

Fields.MenuText: Neither am I, Commander.
Heh. Fanny said you like to take in strays.
I have to think it would be better for her than being picked apart by Morgana locusts.

Fields.DialogueText: It's a rough old beast, war. Isn't it?
It's usually been quite rewarding in the end.
... I still think that's a terrible waste of a lovely name, you know.
Commander, sinking her isn't the plan. We just need to be-
*ALARM*
Damn.
I'm sorry, Captain. I wish I had working guns over here, but....
It's fine. Keep your distance as best you can!
@BATTLE
*BOOM*
Did we get it?
Get back to the radio, Mr. Cassel! Tell the Commander we've taken care of the submarines, but the battleship group is incoming!
He's not going to be able to get back to us before the shooting starts, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: You think!?
Then I guess we have no choice but to save the Hope.
This isn't the time for a conversation!

Fields.DialogueText: Ja! Right!
Ja. I guess you're right. I'll let him know.
Sorry! I'll let him know!
Kanchou!
Miss Kirishima, get off the bridge or I'll have you carried off! This isn't-
Something's wrong with the Hope's engines!

Fields.MenuText: What?
Of course there is.
We're already intercepting the enemy fleet! Everything that can be done is being done!

Fields.DialogueText: She's dead in the water!
Kanchou, she's dead in the water!
But...
Sayako, I know you mean well, but shooting's about to start and I need you to get to where you're supposed to be. We'll keep an eye on Hope.
... Hai! I'm sorry to have troubled you, Kanchou!
Commander Granville, I hope you're keeping your head down....
@BATTLE
Mr. Cassel, do whatever you have to - if the Commander is trying to reach us, I want to be sure we know.
Lieutenant McPhee!
I'm a lieutenant?
Battlefield promotion. I need you to organize a boarding party. We couldn't keep bombers away from the Hope, and I need to make sure that the Commander's out of there before she goes down.
And if anybody has any suggestions about how we can feed the Hope some Morgana debris so she can put herself back together, this is the-
Aye-aye, Captain!
Captain! I've managed to raise him!
Good job, Mr. Cassel. You had us worried, Commander. What's the situation?
It's the damnedest thing, Captain. I seem to have misplaced my left leg.
That's not funny.
... Mr. Cassel, go find Fanny.
That's not funny at all, Bertie.
August. Go. Find Sayako too, if you can.
But...
I'm afraid time's of the essence, my boy. Hope's... Hope's doing something for the pain, bless her heart, but....
I'll tell Enoch to get the Doctor on the boarding party, Captain!

Fields.MenuText: Fine - but hurry!
August. Please, just get Fanny.
You have your orders, Mr. Cassel!

Fields.DialogueText: I... right. Talk to you soon, Commander!
They did something to Hope. The other - I'm not going to call them "Morganas" - but she had some kind of seizure. And the... I don't know, the engine just....
We saw.
The buoys are ready. You'll be able to find where she went down. She thinks she'll be able to whisper to Belles who are looking for her too.
And she thinks... she thinks she'll be back before the end. Of course, she's in worse shape than I am, so....

Fields.MenuText: You're not in pain?
It was an honor to serve with you, Commander.
Save your strength.

Fields.DialogueText: Mm. Did you say Fanny was coming?
Yes. She's-
Non. Non! Albert, this is absolutely unacceptable! Capitaine, tell him!
Sorry, old stick. The Captain told me I should get out, but... you know me. Stubborn streak.
... I'll be outside.
Attendez. Capitaine, can you marry us after all?
Over the radio?
Careful, love. Mustn't... mustn't sound like a gold-digger.
Oui! Yes! I'll take what I can get.
I-
I'm there already.
Right away, Captain. I'll fetch her.
Shouldn't have to for... much longer. Fanny?
It hasn't killed me. Wouldn't dream of letting it. Fanny's on her way.
I'll never tell.
I always said she was cursed.
What's that?
The Lune. The False Hope chewed her up and turned her into engines, da? And then the engines died at the worst possible moment?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe.
I'm not sure there was a "best possible time."
Keep it to yourself, Mr. Lugin.

Fields.DialogueText: The thing about curses, though, is that they're not the end of the story. When it's all said and done, you pick yourself up, stagger along, and do the best you can until the next curse hits you.
Mm.
I liked the old man, though. I always assume everyone is lying all the time, but I think maybe one or two of his stories might have been true.
"There's no such thing as False Hope."
Hm?
The Morgana Belle said that at one point. "There's no such thing as False Hope."
Da. Well, she sank, didn't she?
That's not what I-
*ALARM*
At least I had time to finish my smoke.
@BATTLE
Cursed.
Capitaine! I need to talk to you.
I'm here. You can see the lights of Brest through the mist, by the way. If you squint.
Then the lights should be blacked out, surely.
Probably. How are you holding up?
That... is a very foolish question. You'll have to try to be more clever than this - you're about to become a symbol.
A symbol of what, exactly?
Capitaine, you remember Bertie had a plan. Revitalize the League of Nations, create a united front against the common foe, save the world.
Yes.
He would have done it. In his silly, avuncular way, he would have inspired the right people to dream the right dreams. He would have called out his friends and it would have made all the difference.
My way will be messier. It will be less friendly. But, as God is my witness, it will happen.
There will be a conference in Zurich, leaders will be bribed or terrified into attending, and we will fix this mess.

And you, my friend, are the captain of the ship that came home with film of a doomsday weapon, a hold full of Morgana secrets and an international crew working in harmony. You're going to be a legend.
I will give you the chance to astonish the world, and you are going to succeed. You hear me?
That can be your wedding present.

Fields.MenuText: Y'know... I think I actually believe you.
Fanny, that's a lot for you to take on. You're allowed to stop and breathe.
... A cheese board? Really?

Fields.DialogueText: There. That's the clever mind we need.
No. I'm not. I am absolutely not. I am Marguerite Granville, and I do not yield.
Even in war we must have cheese.
I will be leaving the ship at Brest. Sayako will be staying, if you'll have her.
Though I could also do with a good cheese board, if you're feeling generous.
And Bertie has... had... has a biological daughter, too. By some horrid Paris dancing girl. I might send her to you - she's always had unhealthy ambitions, and I think this would suit.
... Yes. I think that's all.
Okay.
Good.
... Are you going to be okay? And don't tell me it's a foolish question.
Ha! But I really can't think of anything else to say.
Heh.
At least I'll be doing something, Capitaine. I'll be saving the stupid world. And this is how it begins.
... You still have any of that brandy?
I always liked you.
Just saying what's on everyone's mind. Maybe not in their words, but it is there. Better to face it.
"Maybe." The hell with maybes.
